revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=July 2012}} {{Year box}} [[Image:Wildfire Schulte Chicago Cubs.jpg|thumb|200px|right|A cigarette card image of [[baseball]] star [[Frank Schulte]], winner of the [[Major League Baseball Most Valuable Player Award|Chalmers Award]] in 1911]] '''1911 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[American football]]== '''College championship''' * [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|College football national championship]] – [[Princeton Tigers]] '''Events''' * 25 November — the tradition of [[homecoming]] begins at the [[1911 Kansas vs. Missouri football game]].
==[[Association football]]== '''Cyprus''' * [[Anorthosis Famagusta FC]] founded (30 January) '''Egypt''' * [[Zamalek SC]] is founded at [[Gezira Island]], [[Cairo]] as "Thakanat Qasr El-Nil Club" (5 January) '''England''' * [[The Football League]] – [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] 52 points, [[Aston Villa]] 51, [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] 45, [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] 45, [[Bradford City]] 45, [[Sheffield Wednesday|The Wednesday]] 42 * [[1911 FA Cup Final|FA Cup final]] – [[Bradford City A.F.C.|Bradford City]] 1–0 [[Newcastle United]] at [[Crystal Palace National Sports Centre|Crystal Palace]], London (replay following 0–0 draw at Crystal Palace) '''Germany''' * [[List of German football champions|National Championship]] – [[Viktoria Berlin]] 3–1 [[VfB Leipzig]] at Dresden '''Scotland''' * [[Scottish Football League]] – [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] * [[1911 Scottish Cup Final|Scottish Cup]] – [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] 2–0 [[Hamilton Academical F.C.|Hamilton Academical]] at [[Ibrox Stadium|Ibrox Park]]
==[[Australian rules football]]== '''VFL Premiership''' * [[Essendon Football Club|Essendon]] wins the 15th [[Australian Football League|VFL]] Premiership: Essendon 5.11 (41) d [[Collingwood Football Club|Collingwood]] 4.11 (35) at [[Melbourne Cricket Ground]] (MCG)
==[[Bandy]]== '''Sweden''' * [[Allsvenskan and Elitserien (bandy)|Championship final]] – [[IFK Uppsala Bandy|IFK Uppsala]] 6–0 [[Djurgårdens IF Bandy|Djurgårdens IF]]
==[[Baseball]]== '''World Series''' * 14–26 October — [[Philadelphia Athletics]] (AL) defeats [[New York Giants (NL)|New York Giants]] (NL) to win the [[1911 World Series]] by 4 games to 2 '''Events''' * [[Major League Baseball Most Valuable Player Award|Chalmers Award]] – [[Frank Schulte]], NL; [[Ty Cobb]], AL
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * [[Monte Attell]] loses his [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship to Frankie Conley, but Conley holds the title a matter of days before losing to [[Johnny Coulon]] '''Lineal world champions'''<ref>[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm Cyber Boxing Zone]</ref> * [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Jack Johnson (boxer)|Jack Johnson]] * [[World Light Heavyweight Champion]]ship – vacant * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – vacant * [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship – vacant * [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship – [[Ad Wolgast]] * [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship – [[Abe Attell]] * [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship – [[Monte Attell]] → Frankie Conley → [[Johnny Coulon]]
==[[Canadian football]]== '''Grey Cup''' * 25 November — [[3rd Grey Cup]] – [[University of Toronto Varsity Blues]] 14–7 [[Toronto Argonauts]]
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * [[Warwickshire CCC|Warwickshire]] wins its first-ever [[County Championship]] title, the first of the competition's "new clubs" to do so '''England''' * [[County Championship]] – [[Warwickshire CCC|Warwickshire]] * [[Minor Counties Championship]] – [[Staffordshire CCC|Staffordshire]] * Most runs – [[Phil Mead]] 2562 @ 54.51 (HS 223) * Most wickets – [[Harry Dean (cricketer)|Harry Dean]] 183 @ 17.43 (BB 9–109) * [[Wisden Cricketers of the Year]] – [[Frank Foster (cricketer)|Frank Foster]], [[J W Hearne]], [[Sep Kinneir]], [[Phil Mead]], [[Herbert Strudwick]] '''Australia''' * [[Sheffield Shield]] – [[New South Wales cricket team|New South Wales]] * Most runs – [[Aubrey Faulkner]] 1534 @ 59.00 (HS 204) * Most wickets – [[Bill Whitty]] 70 @ 20.27 (BB 6–17) '''India''' * [[Bombay Quadrangular|Bombay Triangular]] – [[Europeans cricket team|Europeans]] shared with [[Hindus cricket team|Hindus]] '''New Zealand''' * [[Plunket Shield]] – [[Canterbury cricket team|Canterbury]] '''South Africa''' * [[SuperSport Series|Currie Cup]] – [[Natal cricket team|Natal]] '''West Indies''' * [[Inter-Colonial Tournament]] – [[Barbados cricket team|Barbados]]
==[[Cycling]]== '''Tour de France''' * [[Gustave Garrigou]] (France) wins the 9th [[List of Tour de France winners|Tour de France]]
==[[Figure skating]]== '''World Figure Skating Championships''' * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Men's Champion]] – Ulrich Salchow (Sweden) * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Women's Champion]] – Lily Kronberger (Hungary) * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Pairs Champions]] – Ludowika Jakobsson-Eilers / Walter Jakobsson (Finland)
==[[Golf]]== '''Events''' * [[John McDermott (golfer)|John McDermott]] becomes both the first American-born man and the youngest golfer (19 years, 10 months) to win the US Open '''Major tournaments''' * [[1911 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Harry Vardon]] * [[1911 U.S. Open (golf)|US Open]] – [[John McDermott (golfer)|John McDermott]] '''Other tournaments''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – [[Harold Hilton]] * [[United States Amateur Championship (men's golf)|US Amateur]] – [[Harold Hilton]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1911 Grand National|Grand National]] – Glenside * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Atmah]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Sunstar]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – Sunstar * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – [[Cherimoya (horse)|Cherimoya]] * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Prince Palatine]] '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – The Parisian '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – St. Bass '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – Reparator II * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – Shanballymore '''USA''' * [[1911 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – Meridian * [[Preakness Stakes]] – Watervale * [[Belmont Stakes]] – ''not contested due to anti-betting legislation in New York State''
==[[Ice hockey]]== '''Stanley Cup''' * March — [[Ottawa Senators (original)|Ottawa Hockey Club]] wins the [[National Hockey Association]] (NHA) championship and [[Stanley Cup]] * 16 March — Ottawa forward Marty Walsh scores 10 goals in a 13–4 win over Port Arthur Seniors in a Stanley Cup challenge. His tally is second in Stanley Cup history to Frank McGee's 14-goal total on 16 January 1905. '''Events''' * March — [[Winnipeg Victorias]] wins the [[1911 Allan Cup|Allan Cup]] * 13 November — NHA founding team [[Renfrew Creamery Kings]] drops out of the league and the players under contract are dispersed to other teams. Two franchises are sold to Toronto interests who intend to start in the 1911–12 season, but Toronto's new [[Arena Gardens]] is not ready for play. * 7 December — upon completion of artificial ice rinks in [[Vancouver]] and [[Victoria, British Columbia]], the new professional [[Pacific Coast Hockey Association]] (PCHA) league is created by former NHA players [[Frank Patrick (ice hockey)|Frank]] and [[Lester Patrick]]. A bidding war for players ensues with numerous NHA players leaving to play in the PCHA.
==[[Motorsport]]== {{main|1911 in motorsport}}
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 1 April — [[Oxford University Boat Club|Oxford]] wins the 68th [[The Boat Race 1911|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]]
==[[Rugby league]]== '''England''' * [[Rugby Football League Championship|Championship]] – [[Oldham R.L.F.C.|Oldham]] * [[Challenge Cup|Challenge Cup final]] – [[Broughton Rangers]] 4–0 [[Wigan Warriors|Wigan]] at [[The Willows, Salford|The Willows]], [[Salford, Greater Manchester|Salford]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Lancashire League Championship]] – [[Wigan Warriors|Wigan]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Yorkshire League Championship]] – [[Wakefield Trinity]] * [[RFL Lancashire Cup|Lancashire]] [[Rugby league county cups|County Cup]] – [[Oldham R.L.F.C.|Oldham]] 4–3 [[Swinton Lions|Swinton]] * [[RFL Yorkshire Cup|Yorkshire]] [[Rugby league county cups|County Cup]] – [[Wakefield Trinity]] 8–2 [[Huddersfield Giants|Huddersfield]] '''Australia''' * [[New South Wales Rugby League premiership|NSW Premiership]] – [[Sydney Roosters|Eastern Suburbs]] 11–8 [[Glebe (rugby league team)|Glebe]] (grand final)
==[[Rugby union]]== '''Five Nations Championship''' * 29th [[1911 Five Nations Championship|Five Nations Championship]] series is won by [[Wales national rugby union team|Wales]] who complete the inaugural [[Grand Slam (rugby union)|Grand Slam]] by defeating all four of its opponents
==[[Speed skating]]== '''Speed Skating World Championships''' * [[1911 World Allround Speed Skating Championships|Men's All-round Champion]] – [[Nikolay Strunnikov]] (Russia)
==[[Tennis]]== '''Australia''' * [[List of Australian Open Men's Singles champions|Australian Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Norman Brookes]] (Australia) defeats [[Horace Rice]] (Australia) 6–1 6–2 6–3 '''England''' * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Anthony Wilding]] (New Zealand) defeats [[Herbert Barrett]] (GB) 6–4 4–6 2–6 6–2 retired * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Dorothea Douglass Lambert Chambers]] defeats [[Dora Boothby]] 6–0 6–0 '''France''' * [[List of French Open Men's Singles champions and finalists|French Men's Singles Championship]] – [[André Gobert]] defeats [[Maurice Germot]]: details unknown * [[List of French Open Women's Singles champions|French Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Jeanne Matthey]] defeats [[Marguerite Broquedis]]: details unknown '''USA''' * [[US Open (tennis)|American Men's Singles Championship]] – [[William Larned]] defeats [[Maurice McLoughlin]] 6–4 6–4 6–2 * [[US Open (tennis)|American Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Hazel Hotchkiss Wightman]] defeats [[Florence Sutton]] 8–10 6–1 9–7 '''Davis Cup''' * [[1911 International Lawn Tennis Challenge]] – {{davis|Australasia}} 4–0 {{davis|USA|1908}} at [[Hagley Park (New Zealand)|Hagley Park]] (grass) [[Christchurch]], New Zealand
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year 1901 – 1950}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:1911 in sports}} [[Category:Sports by year]] [[Category:1911 in sports| ]]

4.35 mi (7.0 km) junior men
2.8 mi (4.5 km) women |Website = |Previous = [[1967 International Cross Country Championships|1967 Barry]] |Next = [[1969 International Cross Country Championships|1969 Clydebank]] }} The '''1968 [[International Cross Country Championships]]''' was held in [[Tunis]], [[Tunisia]], at the [[Tunis#Sport|Hippodrome de Kassar-Said]] on March 17, 1968. The women's championship was held one week later in [[Blackburn]], [[England]] at the [[Witton Country Park]] on March 23, 1968. A report on the men's event {{ Citation | last = | first = | date = March 18, 1968 | title = Athletics - Scotland Fourth in International Cross-country - Tunis, Sunday - Inspired by ageless Andrew Brown, Scotland's senior team in the International Cross-country championship here yesterday produced probably their best result for 32 years when they finished fourth behind England, France, and Spain in that order... | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=tn5AAAAAIBAJ&sjid=uKMMAAAAIBAJ&pg=5389%2C2962199 | publisher = [[Glasgow Herald]] | page = 5 | language = | accessdate = October 4, 2013 }} as well as on the women's event {{ Citation | last = Marshall | first = Ron | date = March 25, 1968 | title = Athletics - Mrs Brown an easy winner - Mrs D. Brown (U.S.A.), one of the best milers in the world, retained the women's International cross-country title on Saturday at Blackburn... | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=vH5AAAAAIBAJ&sjid=uKMMAAAAIBAJ&pg=5725%2C4291995 | publisher = [[Glasgow Herald]] | page = 11 | language = | accessdate = October 4, 2013 }} was given in the [[Glasgow Herald]]. [[Sadd Sports Club|Al-Sadd]] were crowned champions for the first time. ==Results== {{4TeamBracket-Tennis3 | RD1=Semi-finals | RD2=Final | score-width=30px | team-width=160px | RD1-seed1={{flagicon|QAT}} | RD1-team1=[[Al-Gharafa Sports Club|Al-Ittihad]] | RD1-score1-1=1 | RD1-score1-2=3 | RD1-score1-3=4 (3) | RD1-seed2={{flagicon|QAT}} | RD1-team2='''[[Al-Arabi SC (Qatar)|Al-Arabi]]''' | RD1-score2-1=0 | RD1-score2-2=4 | RD1-score2-3=4 (4) | RD1-seed3={{flagicon|QAT}} | RD1-team3='''[[Sadd Sports Club|Al-Sadd]]''' | RD1-score3-1=2 | RD1-score3-2=0 | RD1-score3-3=2 (3) | RD1-seed4={{flagicon|QAT}} | RD1-team4=[[Al-Rayyan Sports Club|Al-Rayyan]] | RD1-score4-1=2 | RD1-score4-2=0 | RD1-score4-3=2 (2) | RD2-seed1={{flagicon|QAT}} | RD2-team1=[[Al-Arabi SC (Qatar)|Al-Arabi]] | RD2-score1-1=2 | RD2-seed2={{flagicon|QAT}} | RD2-team2='''[[Sadd Sports Club|Al-Sadd]]''' | RD2-score2-1=3 }} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center; margin: 0 auto;" |- !1998 Qatar Crown Prince Cup

revision.text:
{{Infobox Racecourse |Name = Ankara 75th Anniversary Race Course
Ankara 75. Yıl Hipodromu |Image= |Caption= |Location= [[Batıkent]], [[Yenimahalle, Ankara|Yenimahalle]], [[Ankara]], Turkey {{Location map | Turkey | width = | float = | border = | caption = | alt = | relief = | AlternativeMap = | label = Ankara
75. Yıl
Hipodromu | label_size = 80 | position = | background = | mark = Horseracingicon.svg | marksize = 20 | link = | lat_deg = 39.96942 | lon_deg = 32.68218 }} |Owner= Jockey Club of Turkey (TJK) |Channel= TJK TV[http://www.tjk.org/Content/CanliYayin.aspx TJK TV Live] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111215142258/http://www.tjk.org/Content/CanliYayin.aspx |date=2011-12-15 }} |Opened= {{start date and age|1998}} |CourseType= [[Flat racing|Flat]]/[[Thoroughbred horse racing|Thoroughbred]] |Website= |NotableRaces = *Republic of Turkey Stakes (since 1981) *Presidency Cup (since 1939) *Grand National Assembly of Turkey Cup (since 1951) *Queen Elizabeth II Cup (since 1971) *Ankara Stakes (since 1950) }} '''Ankara 75th Anniversary Race Course''' ({{lang-tr|Ankara 75. Yıl Hipodromu}}) is a [[horse racing]] [[race track|track]] located at [[Batıkent]] neighborhood in [[Yenimahalle, Ankara|Yenimahalle]] district of [[Ankara]], [[Turkey]]. It is founded in 1998, which was the 75th anniversary of Turkish Republic's foundation.{{cite web |url=http://www.iddaa-tahmin.com/forum/ankara-75-yil-hipodromu-bilgileri-t112412.html |publisher=idaa tahmin |title=Ankara 75. Yıl Hipodromu Bilgileri |language=Turkish |accessdate=2011-11-16 }} ==Physical attributes== The race course covers an area of {{convert|138.3|ha|acre|abbr=on}} consisting of facilities for racing, training and barns. The race course has three tracks as: *a {{convert|2200|m|yd|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|30|m|ft|abbr=on}} wide turf oval, *a {{convert|2055|m|yd|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|20|m|ft|abbr=on}} wide sand track and *a {{convert|1900|m|yd|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|15|m|ft|abbr=on}} wide oval training. The track's total spectator capacity is 8,700 with 2,300 seats. The complex, built on four storeys, comprises offices, social and recreational facilities. ==Major races== *'''Republic of Turkey Stakes''' (Cumhuriyet Koşusu) is the most prestigious [[flat racing]] in Turkey after the [[Gazi Race]], which is run at [[Veliefendi Race Course]] in [[Istanbul]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sporbul.com/spor/y/23728/safkanlar-cumhuriyet-ve-cumhurbaskani-icin-kosacak.html |publisher=SporBul |title=Safkanlar Cumhuriyet ve Cumhurbaşkanı İçin Koşacak.. |language=Turkish |accessdate=2011-11-16 }} Established in 1981, it is held on the last weekend of October ([[Republic Day#October|Republic Day, 29 October]]). 22 purebred [[Arabian horse]]s that are 3-year-old and older compete over a distance of {{convert|1600|m|yd|abbr=on}} on the turf track. The winner is awarded a total money prize of TL 1.275 million (approx. US$900,000 as of October 2010){{cite web |url=http://www.sporx.com/atyarisi/75-yil-ankara-hipodromunda-tarihi-gunSXHBQ211352SXQ |publisher=Spor |title=75. Yıl Ankara Hipodromu'nda tarihi gün |date=2010-10-29 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2011-11-16 }} accompanied by a trophy bestowed by the Turkish president. *'''Presidency Cup''' (Cumhurbaşkanlığı Koşusu), held since 1939 in honor of the Turkish president, is the country's another prestigious [[flat racing]]. It is run on the same day with Republic Race over a distance of {{convert|2400|m|yd|abbr=on}} on the turf track by 9 to 14 [[horse|thoroughbred horse]]s that are 3-year-old and older. The award totals to TL 743,750 (approx. US$520,000 as of October 2010) and a trophy bestowed by the Turkish president.{{cite web |url=http://www.birincikuvvet.com/haber/spor/72-cumhurbaskanligi-kupasi-ve-cumhuriyet-kosusu-75-yil-hipodromunda-yapildi---spor--haberleri/305209.html |publisher=Birinci Kuvvet |title=72. Cumhurbaşkanlığı Kupası Ve Cumhuriyet Koşusu 75. Yıl Hipodromunda Yapıldı |date=2010-10-30 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2011-11-16 }} ==References== {{reflist}} {{coord|39.96942|N|32.68218|E|type:landmark|display=title}} {{Ankara}} [[Category:Horse racing venues in Turkey]] [[Category:Sports venues in Ankara]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1998]] [[Category:Yenimahalle, Ankara]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Athleticrace | bgcolour = | image = | imagesize = | caption = | date = June | location = [[Lubec, Maine|Lubec]], [[Maine]], United States | type = Road | distance = [[Marathon]] | est = 2013 | record = | homepage = [http://bayoffundymarathon.com/ Bay of Fundy Marathon] }} The '''Bay of Fundy International Marathon''' is a [[marathon]] between [[Lubec, Maine]], United States and [[Campobello Island]], [[New Brunswick]], Canada. A 10K is also organized alongside the marathon. The 10K takes place entirely within Lubec.<ref name="Cox">{{cite news|url=http://bangordailynews.com/2014/06/11/sports/bay-of-fundy-international-marathon-runners-to-flock-down-east/|title=Bay of Fundy International Marathon runners to flock Down East|last=Cox|first=Tim|date=June 11, 2014|work=[[Bangor Daily News]]|accessdate=15 June 2014}}</ref>
The race begins at [[West Quoddy Head Lighthouse]], which is the eastern most point in the United States. Runners cross the [[Franklin Delano Roosevelt Bridge]] connecting Maine to New Brunswick and run until they reach [[Head Harbour Lighthouse]] (East Quoddy Lighthouse), at which time the runners turn around and return to Lubec.<ref name="Cox"/>
The first marathon was run in 2013. It included over 500 registered runners and was held in June. The race provided significant economic benefits to the area. The 2014 edition featured fewer runners (286 total). The organizers attributed the decrease to the "Boston effect" whereas marathon runners chose other marathons in run in order to qualify for the [[2014 Boston Marathon]].<ref name="Cox"/>
==External links== * [http://www.marathonguide.com/races/racedetails.cfm?MIDD=4703140615 Bay of Fundy International Marathon & 10K Lubec, ME USA]
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2012}} {{Infobox stadium | image = | stadium_name = Belson Stadium | nickname = | location = 8000 [[Utopia Parkway (Queens)|Utopia Parkway]]
[[Queens]], [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|NY]] 11439 | coordinates = | broke_ground = February 1, 2001 | opened = September 21, 2002 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[St. John's University (New York City)|St. John's University]] | operator = St. John's University | surface = [[FieldTurf]] | construction_cost = $6 million | architect = | structural engineer = | general_contractor = | former_names = | tenants = [[St. John's Red Storm]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) (2002–present)
[[New York Pancyprian-Freedoms]] ([[United States Adult Soccer Association|USASA]]) (2005–present)
[[F.C. New York]] ([[USL Pro]]/[[National Premier Soccer League|NPSL]]) (2011–2012)
[[New York Cosmos (2010)|New York Cosmos]] ([[North American Soccer League|NASL]]) (2015–2016) ([[Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup|USOC]] matches and [[Soccer Bowl 2016]])
[[New York Rumble]] ([[Major League Ultimate|MLU]]) (2015)
[[F.A. Euro]] ([[Premier Development League|PDL]]) (2016–present) | seating_capacity = 2,168 | dimensions = }} '''Belson Stadium''' is a 2,168 seat [[soccer-specific stadium]] located at [[Utopia Parkway (Queens)|Utopia Parkway]] and [[Union Turnpike (New York)|Union Turnpike]] in [[Queens]], [[New York City]], on the campus of [[St. John's University (New York City)|St. John's University]]. It is the home of the [[St. John's Red Storm]] men's and women's soccer teams. The stadium is unique in that it is built on top of a parking garage to save space in the dense urban environment of Queens.{{cite web|title=BELSON SOCCER STADIUM|url=https://redstormsports.com/sports/2018/6/12/facilities-stjo-belson-stadium-html.aspx|website=St. John's University Athletics|accessdate=3 November 2016}} The stadium is named in honor of Maxine and Jerome Belson. Mr. Belson was a graduate of St. John’s law school, a member of the university’s Board of Trustees and a past benefactor to the university. The Belsons donated $6 million for the construction of the stadium and an additional $5 million was raised for the parking garage and landscaping.{{cite web|url=http://www.qchron.com/editions/north/st-john-s-university-dedicates-new-belson-soccer-stadium/article_30aba26b-88a0-5a46-8269-65893c8b824f.html|title=St. John’s University Dedicates New Belson Soccer Stadium|publisher=Queens Chronicle|date=September 26, 2002|accessdate=August 9, 2017}} In 2013, the stadium became the home field of [[F.A. Euro|F.A. Euro New York]] of the [[Premier Development League]] (PDL).{{cite web|url=http://www.uslpdl.com/page/show/3155151-fa-euro-new-york|title=FA Euro New York|publisher=uslpdl.com|accessdate=August 10, 2017}} On November 13, 2016, the stadium hosted the [[Soccer Bowl 2016|Soccer Bowl]], the champions game of the [[North American Soccer League]] (NASL), between the [[New York Cosmos (2010)|New York Cosmos]] and the [[Indy Eleven]]. The Cosmos won on [[Penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalties]] 4-2 in front of a crowd of 2,150.{{cite web|url=https://www.nysportsday.com/2016/11/14/modern-dynasty-cosmos-win-8th-nasl-title-2nd-straight-and-3rd-in-4-years/|title=Modern Dynasty: Cosmos Win 8th NASL Title (2nd Straight and 3rd in 4 Years)|publisher=nysportsday.com|date=November 14, 2016|accessdate=August 10, 2017}} The Cosmos also played several [[Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup|U.S. Open Cup]] matches at the stadium in 2015 and 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.empireofsoccer.com/belson-stadium-to-host-cosmos-revolution-match-49727/|title=Belson Stadium to host Cosmos, Revolution match|publisher=empireofsoccer.com|date=June 16, 2016|accessdate=August 10, 2017}} The stadium is also the home field of the [[New York Pancyprian-Freedoms]] of the [[Cosmopolitan Soccer League]] of the [[United States Adult Soccer Association]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nypancyprianfreedoms.com/|title=New York of Pancyprian-Freedoms|publisher=New York of Pancyprian-Freedoms|date=August 10, 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/09/sports/soccer/new-york-cosmpolitan-league-pancyprian-freedoms.html|title=Amateur Soccer in New York, Built on Immigrant Pride|publisher=New York Times|date=June 9, 2017|accessdate=August 10, 2017}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External Links== *[https://redstormsports.com/sports/2018/6/12/facilities-stjo-belson-stadium-html.aspx Belson Stadium] {{coord|40.724307|-73.792838|region:US-NY_type:landmark_scale:5000_source:Wikimapia|display=title}} {{St. John's University (New York City)}} {{Big East Conference soccer venue navbox}} {{NewYorksportsvenues}} {{Premier Development League stadiums}} [[Category:Sports venues in Queens, New York]] [[Category:St. John's Red Storm soccer]] [[Category:Soccer venues in New York (state)]] [[Category:F.C. New York]] [[Category:Jamaica, Queens]] [[Category:College soccer venues in the United States]] [[Category:2002 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2002]] [[Category:Ultimate (sport) venues]] {{QueensNY-struct-stub}} {{NewYork-sports-venue-stub}} {{NYC-sport-stub}}

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Bob Wren Stadium| nickname = | image= File:OU Wren Stadium.JPG | location = [[Athens, Ohio]] | broke_ground = 1997| opened = April 18, 1998 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Ohio University]] | operator = [[Ohio University]] | surface = [[Nature|Natural]] [[Grass]] | construction_cost = $2 million[[United States dollar|USD]] | architect = various| former_names = | tenants = [[Ohio Bobcats baseball|Ohio Bobcats]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) (1998–Present)
[[Southern Ohio Copperheads]] ([[Great Lakes Summer Collegiate League|GLSCL]]) (2002–Present) | seating_capacity = 4,000 | dimensions = Left Field - 340 ft.
Left Field Alley - 380 ft.
Center Field - 405 ft.
Right Field Alley - 380 ft.
Right Field - 340 ft.}} '''Bob Wren Stadium''' is a [[baseball]] stadium located in [[Athens, Ohio]] on the campus of [[Ohio University]]. It serves as the home field for the [[Ohio Bobcats baseball|Ohio Bobcats]] since opening on April 18, 1998. The Bobcats opened the facility by defeating the [[Bowling Green Falcons baseball|Bowling Green Falcons]] 4–1 in front of 1,389 fans. [[File:OU Bob Wren Statue.JPG|left|thumb|A statue of Bob Wren located just outside the stadium]] Bob Wren Stadium features many modern amenities and has a capacity of 4,000. The stadium has 100 chairback seats that are part of the VIP club, named the Baumholtz club in honor of former Ohio baseball player Frank Baumholtz. In addition, there are around 1,000 bleacher-back seats in the stadium and another 1,000 seats of regular bleachers. Down both the third and first base lines there are two grassy knolls that are capable of seating up to another 1,000 fans. There are two concession stands available with traditional ballpark fare, and members of the Baumholtz Club have access to a private lounge that serves more upscale food items. The press box provides multiple phones and computer lines for members of the media. There are also two radio broadcast booths and one television broadcast booth available. The stadium has already undergone several modifications since opening. In 2003, a large Daktronics digital scoreboard was added to the outfield of the stadium. That same year, heated batting cages were added to the northeast of the stadium, allowing Bobcat players to practice inside during cold weather. Most recently, lights were installed in 2004. As a result of this new addition, 15 of Ohio's 28 home games in 2005 were played at night. The stadium is named for former Bobcat head coach Bob Wren, who held the highest all-time winning percentage of any Ohio baseball coach. In addition to serving as the home of Ohio Bobcats baseball, Bob Wren Stadium is home to the [[Southern Ohio Copperheads]] of the [[Great Lakes Summer Collegiate League]] and is the home of the state [[American Legion]] baseball tournament every year. ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I baseball venues]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://ohiobobcats.collegesports.com/facilities/wren-stadium.html}} {{Ohio University}} {{Mid-American Conference baseball venue navbox}} {{Ohio NCAA Division I college baseball venue navbox}} {{coord|39.324491|-82.10895|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Ohio Bobcats baseball]] [[Category:College baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Buildings and structures of Ohio University]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Ohio]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Athens County, Ohio]] [[Category:1998 establishments in Ohio]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1998]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Website | name = FanGraphs | logo = | screenshot = | caption = | url = [http://www.fangraphs.com/ fangraphs.com] | alexa = {{DecreasePositive}} 12,496 ({{as of|2014|4|1|alt=April 2014}})<ref name="alexa">{{cite web|url= https://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/fangraphs.com |title= Fangraphs.com Site Info | publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate= 2014-04-01 }}</ref> | commercial = | type = [[Baseball]] statistics and analysis | registration = | owner = | author = David Appelman | developer = | operating_system = | launch date = | current status = Active | revenue = }}
'''FanGraphs.com''' is a website run by Fangraphs Inc., located in [[Arlington, Virginia]], and created and owned by David Appelman that provides statistics for every player in [[Major League Baseball]] history.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/tos.aspx |title=Terms of Service | FanGraphs Baseball |publisher=Fangraphs.com |date= |accessdate=March 18, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=David Appelman, Fangraphs.com |url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2007/baseball/mlb/02/19/fangraphs.projections/1.html |title=SI.com – MLB – Behind the numbers (cont.) – Monday February 19, 2007 3:43PM |publisher=Sportsillustrated.cnn.com |date=February 19, 2007 |accessdate=March 18, 2010}}</ref>
On September 18, 2009, Fangraphs Inc. launched an [[iPhone]] app in partnership with Hawk Ridge Consulting, which has since been discontinued.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hawkridgeconsulting.com/apple-features-hawk-ridge-developed-app-in-itunes-store-baseball-essentials|title=Apple Features Hawk Ridge|accessdate=May 29, 2011}}</ref> Fangraphs has a number of content partners including [[ESPN]], [[SB Nation]] and [[Fanhouse]].
==FanGraphs products== '''FanGraphs''' creates several products:
===Web sites=== * The FanGraphs homepage,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fangraphs.com |title=Baseball Statistics and Analysis | FanGraphs Baseball |publisher=Fangraphs.com |date=2012-09-28 |accessdate=2012-10-02}}</ref> which contains articles, statistical reports and also covers baseball history as well as current issues and events, including games and series, injuries, forecasts, player profiles, baseball finance, and the player marketplace. * RotoGraphs is FanGraphs' fantasy baseball advice and analysis section. It originally featured David Golebiewski of ESPN Inside Edge, Marc Hulet, Brian Joura of newyorkmetsdaily.com, and Peter Bendix.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.beyondtheboxscore.com/2008/11/3/652785/rotographs|title=Rotographs|accessdate=April 22, 2011|publisher=Beyond the Boxscore}}</ref> Currently managed by Eno Sarris. * NotGraphs provides "a place to put things that would otherwise not have a place on FanGraphs".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/not/index.php/introducing-notgraphs-the-blog/|title=Introducing Notgraphs|accessdate=April 22, 2011|publisher=NotGraphs}}</ref> NotGraphs was managed by Carson Cistulli but ceased publishing new content at the conclusion of the 2014 season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/not/this-weblog-will-expire-in-three-months/|title=This Weblog Will Expire in Three Months|accessdate=January 22, 2015|publisher=NotGraphs}}</ref> * The Community Blog is an opportunity for readers to share their writing through FanGraphs. In May 2010 an editorial staff was put in place to guarantee an "approval process" within 48 hours of submission.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/blogs/index.php/community-blog-guidelines/|title=Community Blog Guidelines|accessdate=April 22, 2011|publisher=FanGraphs}}</ref> * The FanGraphs Library is an encyclopedia of Sabermetric statistics and principles run by Neil Weinberg.
===Publishing=== * FanGraphs releases an annual book ''The FanGraphs Second Opinion: Fantasy Companion'' that contains statistics and analysis of the past season, in-depth player profiles, team previews, articles on fantasy strategy and forecasts of the upcoming season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/blogs/index.php/the-fangraphs-second-opinion-fantasy-companion/ |title=Second Opinion Fantasy Companion|accessdate=April 22, 2011|publisher=SB Nation}}</ref>
===Podcasts=== * Hosted by FanGraphs editor [[Carson Cistulli]], FanGraphs Audio is a weekly program archived at FanGraphs Audio.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fangraphs.com/blogs/category/podcast/ |title=FanGraphs Audio| FanGraphs Baseball |publisher=Fangraphs.com |date= |accessdate=2018-01-11}}</ref> *Hosted by Ben Lindbergh and Jeff Sullivan, Effectively Wild is a thrice weekly podcast.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fangraphs.com/blogs/category/effectively-wild/|title=Effectively Wild| FanGraphs Baseball |publisher=Fangraphs.com |date= |accessdate=2018-01-11}}</ref> Effectively Wild was initially created as a part of [[Baseball Prospectus]], but moved over to FanGraphs at the beginning of 2017 when one of its former hosts, Sam Miller, left the podcast to work at ESPN.
===Fantasy Baseball=== * FanGraphs works with Ottoneu baseball to offer a fantasy baseball program<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/blogs/index.php/introducing-ottoneu-fantasy-baseball/|title=Introducing Ottoneu Fantasy Baseball|accessdate=May 15, 2011|publisher=FanGraphs}}</ref> with prizes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/fantasy/index.php/ottoneu-now-has-prizes/|title=Ottoneau Now Has Prizes|accessdate=May 15, 2011|publisher=FanGraphs}}</ref>
==Regular writers==
===FanGraphs===
* '''[[Carson Cistulli]]''' – Senior writer of FanGraphs, former editor of NotGraphs and host of the FanGraphs Audio podcast. Joined in August, 2009. Cistulli is responsible for the Daily Notes and writes the "Fringe Five" prospect feature. He previously worked for [[The Hardball Times]]. * '''Jeff Sullivan''' – Senior writer of FanGraphs and editor of the Community blog. Joined in August, 2012. Sullivan hosts a weekly chat, contributes to FanGraphs on Fox Sports, writes several features, such as the "Worst of the Best" series and is a co-host of the "Effectively Wild" podcast. He also writes for USSMariner.com and previously wrote for [[SB Nation]]'s Lookout Landing. * '''Paul Swydan''' – Senior writer of FanGraphs. Joined in January, 2011. Swydan is the co-managing editor of The Hardball Times and is a writer for ESPN Insider. He previously worked 7 years for the [[Colorado Rockies]] and wrote for [[Baseball Prospectus]], MLB.com, Rockies Magazine and the Biz Of Baseball. * '''Eric Longenhagen''' – FanGraphs lead prospect analyst. Contributed in 2014 and 2015, but re-joined in May, 2016. Longenhagen previously wrote for Crashburn Alley, Sports on Earth, Prospect Insider and ESPN.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/blogs/a-reintroduction/|title=A Reintroduction {{!}} FanGraphs Baseball|website=www.fangraphs.com|access-date=2016-08-05}}</ref> * '''Chris Mitchell''' – Prospect analyst at FanGraphs and proprietor of the KATOH prospect projection system. Joined February, 2015. Mitchell also contributes to The Hardball Times, and has previously contributed to Pinstripe Alley and Pinstripe Pundits. * '''Kiley McDaniel''' – Prospect analyst at Fangraphs. McDaniel previously worked as the Assistant Director of Baseball Operations with the Atlanta Braves,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/blogs/instagraphs/saying-farewell/|title=Saying Farewell {{!}} FanGraphs Baseball|website=www.fangraphs.com|access-date=2016-08-05}}</ref> and for the [[New York Yankees]], [[Pittsburgh Pirates]] and [[Baltimore Orioles]] and wrote for [[Scout.com]] and [[ESPN]]'s Draft Blog. * '''Tony Blengino''' – Staff writer of FanGraphs. Joined in December, 2013. Blengino analyzes major league players, teams and transactions with an inside look on how front offices use statistics in scouting. He previously worked as a scout with the [[Milwaukee Brewers]] and an assistant to the GM with the [[Seattle Mariners]]. * '''Craig Edwards''' – Staff writer of FanGraphs. Joined in February, 2015. Edwards is also the managing editor of Viva El Birdos. * '''Nathaniel Grow''' – Legal analyst at FanGraphs. Joined in December, 2014. Grow is an Associate Professor of Legal Studies at the University of Georgia's Terry College of Business. He is the author of Baseball on Trial: The Origin of Baseball's Antitrust Exemption, as well as a number of sports-related law review articles. * '''Corinne Landrey''' – Staff writer of FanGraphs. Joined in June, 2016. Landrey also writes for The Hardball Times, Today's Knuckleball and is the managing editor of Crashburn Alley. * '''David Laurila''' – Staff writer of FanGraphs. Joined in May, 2011. Laurila contributes Q&A articles and produces the Sunday Notes column. He is a member of the BBWAA and previously wrote for [[Baseball Prospectus]] where he wrote the Prospectus Q&A from February 2006 until May 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseballprospectus.com/author/david_laurila//|title=Baseball Prospectus - David Laurila|accessdate=September 15, 2011|publisher=[[Baseball Prospectus]]}}</ref> * '''Blake Murphy''' – Staff writer of FanGraphs and RotoGraphs. Joined in July, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/blogs/introducing-the-adam-dunn-hat-trick/|title=Introducing the Adam Dunn Hat Trick |accessdate=August 12, 2014|publisher=FanGraphs}}</ref> Murphy contributes to the Daily Fantasy feature at RotoGraphs. He also serves as the NBA editor for [[theScore Inc.]] and writes for NylonCalculus.com and RaptorsRepublic.com. * '''David G. Temple''' – Staff writer of FanGraphs and NotGraphs. Joined FanGraphs in October, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/blogs/does-the-braves-stuff-work-in-the-playoffs/|title=Does the Braves' Stuff Work in the Playoffs? |accessdate=August 12, 2014|publisher=FanGraphs}}</ref> Temple began writing for NotGraphs in July, 2012. He also contributes to The Hardball Times and is the host of the Stealing Home podcast. He previously contributed to TheClassical.com and ThePlatoonAdvantage.com. * '''Neil Weinberg''' – Site educator of FanGraphs. Joined in July, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/blogs/a-reintroduction-to-the-fangraphs-library/|title=A (Re)Introduction to the FanGraphs Library |accessdate=August 12, 2014|publisher=FanGraphs}}</ref> Weinberg hosts a weekly chat and is responsible for maintaining the FanGraphs statistical library. He also works as a managing editor for [[SB Nation]]'s BeyondtheBoxscore and writes for The Hardball Times, Gammons Daily, TigsTown.com and NewEnglishD.com. * '''Jeff Zimmerman''' – Staff writer of FanGraphs and RotoGraphs. Joined in March, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/blogs/index.php/berkman-officially-on-dl-to-start-season/|title=Berkman Officially on DL to Start Season|accessdate=April 22, 2011|publisher=FanGraphs}}</ref> Zimmerman is the expert on player health and contributes extensive work relating to player aging curves. He contributes the weekly MASH report feature to RotoGraphs. He is also the founder of BaseballHeatMaps.com and writes for [[SB Nation]]'s RoyalsReview.
===RotoGraphs===
* '''Mike Axisa''' (Apr '10 - present)<ref>{{cite web|last=Axisa|first=Mike|title=Starting Pitchers: April 12th|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/fantasy/index.php/starting-pitchers-april-12th/}}</ref> – RotoGraphs staff writer. Also writes for and co-founded River Ave. Blues, a Yankees blog. * '''Michael Barr''' (Feb '11 - present)<ref>{{cite web|last=Barr|first=Michael|title=Fallers at First Base|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/fantasy/index.php/first-base-fallers/}}</ref> – RotoGraphs and FanGraphs staff writer. * '''Howard Bender''' (Feb '11 - present)<ref>{{cite web|last=Bender|first=Howard|title=2011 Player Rankings: Catchers|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/fantasy/index.php/2011-player-rankings-catchers/}}</ref> – Founder of The Fantasy Baseball Buzz, also a contributor to the 2011 Fantasy Baseball Guide magazine and ESPN Radio.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/fantasy/index.php/keeper-league-would-you-rather-joe-mauer-or-alex-avila/|title=Keeper League Would You Rather?: Joe Mauer or Alex Avila|accessdate=September 26, 2011|publisher=RotoGraphs}}</ref> * '''Jason Catania''' (Mar '11 - present)<ref>{{cite web|last=Catania|first=Jason|title=2011 Player Rankings: AL OF|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/fantasy/index.php/2011-player-rankings-american-league-outfielders/}}</ref> – Also writes for ESPN The Magazine and ESPN Insider.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/fantasy/index.php/keeper-strategy-2012-impact-rookies-starting-pitchers/|title=Keeper Strategy — 2012 Impact Rookies: Starting Pitchers|accessdate=September 26, 2011|publisher=RotoGraphs}}</ref> * '''Ben Duronio''' (Jan '12 - present)<ref>{{cite web|last=Duronio|first=Ben|title=Jordan Walden, a Poor Man’s Craig Kimbrel|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/fantasy/index.php/jordan-walden-a-poor-mans-craig-kimbrel/}}</ref> – Also writes for the Capitol Avenue Club, a Braves blog. Worked with ESPN Stats & Info Group. * '''Erik Hahmann''' (Feb '11 - present)<ref>{{cite web|last=Hahmann|first=Erik|title=$1 Catchers: Shoppach and Torrealba|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/fantasy/index.php/1-catchers-shoppach-and-torrealba/}}</ref> – Previously wrote for Bloomberg Sports, also writes for DraysBay.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/fantasy/index.php/pomeranz-and-dickey-streaming-friday-starters/|title=Pomeranz and Dickey Streaming Friday Starters|accessdate=September 26, 2011|publisher=RotoGraphs}}</ref> * '''Marc Hulet''' (Apr '08 - present) – Hulet provides articles and scouting reports on minor league prospects, including annual preseason and midseason top prospect lists. * '''Brad Johnson''' (Oct '13 - present)– Johnson is responsible for The Daily Grind feature at RotoGraphs. Also occasionally contributes to The Hardball Times. * '''Mike Podhorzer''' (Mar '11 - present)<ref>{{cite web|last=Podhorzer|first=Mike|title=$1 NL Outfield Option: Nate McLouth|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/fantasy/index.php/1-nl-outfield-option-nate-mclouth/}}</ref> – Has written for The Fantasy Baseball Generals and FantasyPros911.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/fantasy/index.php/potential-2012-k9-surgers/|title=Potential 2012 K9 Surgers|accessdate=September 26, 2011|publisher=RotoGraphs}}</ref> * '''Zach Sanders''' (Nov '09 - present)<ref>{{cite web|last=Sanders|first=Zach|title=Free Agent Fantasy Impact: Matt Holliday|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/fantasy/index.php/free-agent-fantasy-impact-matt-holliday/}}</ref> – RotoGraphs staff writer and creator of the Roto Riteup, a daily fantasy baseball column which runs through the duration of the MLB season. Sanders also contributes to RotoGraphs' Fantasy Rankings.<ref>{{cite web|last=Sanders|first=Zach|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/fantasy/index.php/end-of-season-rankings-first-base/|title=End of Season Rankings: First Base}}</ref> * '''Dan Wade''' (Aug '11 - present)<ref>{{cite web|last=Wade|first=Dan|title=Santana, Hughes: AL Starting Pitchers|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/fantasy/index.php/santana-hughes-al-starting-pitchers/}}</ref> – RotoGraphs staff writer. * '''Brandon Warne''' (Feb '12 - present)<ref>{{cite web|last=Warne|first=Brandon|title=First Time Ottoneu Owner – Draft Strategy and Rationale|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/fantasy/index.php/first-time-ottoneu-owner-draft-strategy-and-rationale/}}</ref> - Covers two start starting pitchers for Rotographs. Warne is a Minnesota Twins beat reporter for Twin Cities-based website Cold Omaha. * '''David Wiers''' (Mar '12 - present)<ref>{{cite web|last=Wiers|first=David|title=Roto Riteup: March 23rd, 2012|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/fantasy/index.php/roto-riteup-march-23rd-2012/}}</ref> - RotoGraphs staff writer and co-author of the Roto Riteup series.<ref>{{cite web|last=Wiers|first=David|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/fantasy/index.php/roto-riteup-october-19-2012/|title=Roto Riteup: October 19, 2012}}</ref>
===Former=== * '''[[Dave Cameron (baseball analyst)|Dave Cameron]]''' – Was the managing editor and senior writer of FanGraphs. He hosted a weekly chat, contributed to FanGraphs on Fox Sports, wrote several features such as the annual "Trade Value" series and was a regular contributor to the FanGraphs Audio podcast. Cameron was the co-founder of USSMariner.com and previously worked for [[Baseball Prospectus]] and contributed to the [[Wall Street Journal]]. On January 10, 2018, Cameron announced that he would be leaving his job as managing editor in order to take up a job as an analyst for the [[San Diego Padres]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fangraphs.com/blogs/the-one-i-never-thought-i-would-write/ |title=Cameron's Final Blog Post| FanGraphs Baseball |publisher=Fangraphs.com |date= |accessdate=2018-01-11}}</ref> * '''Eno Sarris''' – Senior writer of FanGraphs and editor of RotoGraphs. Joined in July, 2010. Sarris hosted a weekly chat, contributed to FanGraphs on [[Fox Sports]] and NotGraphs and is the founder and operator of [[BeerGraphs]]. He also wrote for the Hardball Times and previously wrote for Bloomberg Sports and Amazin' Avenue * '''RJ Anderson''' – Now writes for [[Baseball Prospectus]]. * '''Patrick Andriola''' - Joined FanGraphs in June, 2010<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/blogs/index.php/ryan-howards-odd-decline/|title=Ryan Howard’s Odd Decline|accessdate=September 28, 2011|publisher=[[FanGraphs]]}}</ref> until October, 2010<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/blogs/index.php/the-roy-oswalt-decision/|title=The Roy Oswalt Decision|accessdate=September 28, 2011|publisher=[[FanGraphs]]}}</ref> Before joining FanGraphs Andriola wrote for [[The Hardball Times]] (2009, 2010) and, as a student, worked for the Major League Baseball's Labor Relations Department.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hardballtimes.com/main/authors/pandriola/2009/ |title=The Hardball Times Authors Page - Pat Andriola |accessdate=September 28, 2011 |publisher=[[The Hardball Times]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402231917/http://www.hardballtimes.com/main/authors/pandriola/2009/ |archivedate=April 2, 2012 |df= }}</ref> * '''Peter Bendix''' – Now works for the [[Tampa Bay Rays]] as an assistant of Baseball Research and Development.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/team/front_office.jsp?c_id=tb|title=Front Office Directory|accessdate=May 25, 2011|publisher=[[MLB.com]]}}</ref> * '''Drew Fairservice''' – Fairservice is the managing editor of GhostRunnerOnFirst.com and previously wrote for the [[theScore Inc.]]. * '''August Fagerstrom''' – Former staff writer of FanGraphs. Joined in June, 2014. Fagerstrom also writes for the [[Akron Beacon Journal]] and ohio.com and has been published in the [[Chicago Tribune]] and [[Washington Post]]. August left FanGraphs at the end of the 2016 season to work for the [[Milwaukee Brewers]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/blogs/instagraphs/logging-off/| title= Logging Off}}</ref> * '''Sky Kalkman''' – Left FanGraphs in 2006, then wrote for Beyond The Boxscore,<ref name="beyondtheboxscore1">{{cite web|url=http://www.beyondtheboxscore.com/ |title=A Saber-Slanted Baseball Community |publisher=Beyondtheboxscore.com |date= |accessdate=2012-10-02}}</ref> and now writes for [[Baseball Prospectus]]. * '''[[Jonah Keri]]''' – Keri joined FanGraphs in January 2011, introduced as having "written for every publication known to man"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/blogs/index.php/success-cycle-is-full-of-crap/|title=The Success Cycle is Full of Crap|accessdate=September 26, 2011|publisher=[[FanGraphs]]}}</ref> -- [[Playboy]], [[ESPN]], and [[Baseball Prospectus]] among others, the author of ''The Extra 2%: How Wall Street Strategies Took a Major League Baseball Team from Worst to First'' (2011). Keri was a staff writer for FanGraphs and NotGraphs until August 2011 when he left to write "full-time" at [[Grantland.com]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/blogs/index.php/jonah-keri-fangraphs-chat-8811/|title=Jonah Keri FanGraphs Chat – 8/8/11|accessdate=September 26, 2011|publisher=[[FanGraphs]]}}</ref> * '''Matt Klaassen''' – Joined in November, 2009 until November 2014. Klaassen was a staff writer and occasionally contributed to the FanGraphs Audio podcast. * '''Erik Manning''' – Now writes for Beyond The Boxscore.<ref name="beyondtheboxscore1" /> * '''Mike Petriello''' – Petriello now writes for MLB.com.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/columnists/?id=mike_petriello|title=Mike Petriello: Columnists|website=Major League Baseball|access-date=2016-08-05}}</ref> He's also contributed to The Hardball Times, ESPN Insider and DodgersDigest.com. He was previously an editor producer for [[Sports on Earth]]. * '''Frankie Piliere''' – Now writes for Scout.com.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scout.com/ |title=College and High School Football, Basketball, Recruiting, NFL, and MLB Front Page |publisher=Scout.com |date= |accessdate=2012-10-02}}</ref> * '''Bryan Smith''' - Wrote for FanGraphs from January, 2010<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/blogs/index.php/staring-down-the-sinkerballers-part-one/|title=Staring Down the Sinkerballers, Part One|accessdate=September 28, 2011|publisher=[[FanGraphs]]}}</ref> until November, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/blogs/index.php/florida-marlins-farm-system-discussion/|title=Florida Marlins Farm System Discussion|accessdate=September 28, 2011|publisher=[[FanGraphs]]}}</ref> * '''Steve Sommer''' - Wrote for FanGraphs from March, 2010<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/blogs/index.php/fans-playoff-probabilities-al-version/|title=FANS Playoff Probabilities – AL Version|accessdate=September 28, 2011|publisher=[[FanGraphs]]}}</ref> until May 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/blogs/index.php/closer-usage-in-the-al-east/|title=Closer Usage in the AL East|accessdate=September 28, 2011|publisher=[[FanGraphs]]}}</ref> Now writes for [[The Hardball Times]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hardballtimes.com/main/authors/steves/2011/ |title=The Hardball Times Authors Page - Steve Sommer |accessdate=September 28, 2011 |publisher=[[The Hardball Times]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111015154244/http://www.hardballtimes.com/main/authors/steves/2011/ |archivedate=October 15, 2011 |df= }}</ref> * '''Nathaniel Stoltz''' – Stoltz was a prospect writer who viewed prospects in the Eastern, Carolina, South Atlantic, and New York-Penn Leagues. He previously wrote at Beyond the Box Score, Athletics Nation, and RotoGraphs. * '''JD Sussman''' – Sussman was a prospect writer who contributed to the Prospect Watch feature. He previously wrote for BullpenBanter.com. * '''Wendy Thurm''' – Thurm was a previous lawyer of 18 years who covered legal issues in baseball. She has previously contributed to [[Sports on Earth]], [[ESPN]], [[SB Nation]], [[theScore Inc.]], BayAreaSportsGuy.com, TheClassical.com and San Francisco Magazine. * '''Bradley Woodrum''' – Woodrum holds degrees from [[Jacksonville University]] (B.A. Economics and B.A. English) and [[Roosevelt University]] (M.A. Economics). He also co-founded Cubs Stats and writes for DRaysBay<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.draysbay.com/|title=DRaysBay, a Tampa Bay Rays community|date=|publisher=Draysbay.com|author=Steve Slowinski|accessdate=2012-10-02}}</ref> and SBN Tampa Bay.

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Gressbanen | nickname = | image = File:Gressbanen IMG 5831.JPG | location = [[Holmen, Oslo|Holmen]], [[Oslo]] | coordinates = {{coord|59|57|03|N|10|40|34|E|type:landmark_source:kolossus-nowiki|display=title,inline}} | broke_ground = | opened = 1 September 1918 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Oslo Municipality | operator = | surface = [[Artificial turf]] (summer)
[[Artificial ice]] (winter) | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[IF Ready]] (1918–)
[[Mercantile SFK]] (1918–47)
[[Norway national football team]] (1919–27)
[[List of Norwegian Football Cup finals|Norwegian Football Cup Final]] (1920–21) | seating_capacity = | record_attendance = 20,000 | dimensions = {{convert|105|x|65|m|yd|abbr=on}} }} '''Gressbanen''' or '''Vestre Holmen''' is a stadium located at [[Holmen, Oslo|Holmen]] in [[Oslo]], [[Norway]]. During summer it has [[artificial turf]] and is used for [[association football]], while during winter it has [[artificial ice]] and fields [[bandy]]. The complex also contains a smaller training field with gravel during summer and natural ice during winter. Gressbanen is the home venue of [[IF Ready]], whose bandy team plays in the [[Norwegian Bandy Premier League]] and who fields 35 recreational football teams. The stadium was built as a response to the need for a grass pitch for the [[Norway national football team]], as well as to serve as a home to Ready and [[Mercantile SFK]]. It opened on 1 September 1918 as the second grass pitch in Norway and the first in Oslo. As such it replaced [[Frogner Stadion]] as the home of the national team, for which it was home to seventeen matches. The national team moved to [[Ullevaal Stadion]] in 1927. Gressbanen also featured two [[List of Norwegian Football Cup finals|Norwegian Football Cup Final]], in [[1920 Norwegian Football Cup Final|1920]] and [[1921 Norwegian Football Cup Final|1921]]. The pitch has been iced and used for bandy since 1935. Mercantile remained a tenant until 1947, when it merged with [[SFK Trygg]]. Gressbanen received artificial turf in 2001 and artificial ice in 2004. ==History== During the 1910s there were no grass football pitches in Norway. At the time the only proper football fields in Oslo were [[Bislett Stadion]] and Frogner Stadion, the latter which was at first used by the national team.Larsen: 82 The Football Association of Norway took initiative in 1911 to study the possibility for a grass field and conducted visits to [[Idrætsparken]] in [[Copenhagen]] and [[Stockholm Olympic Stadium]] to investigate how the neighboring capitals had resolved the issue.Larsen: 83 The main concern was that a grass field located in the Norwegian climate would not survive the winter. Also financing was a challenge, as none of the local clubs, nor the federation, had capital to construct a grass venue. In 1914 the Norway national team had lost 7–0 against Sweden on the grass pitch at [[Råsunda Stadium]], with the press stating that "grass has become our ruin", pointing out how the Norwegian players were unable to handle the wet surface.Larsen: 84 [[File:Gressbanen grandstand 1925.jpg|thumb|left|Gressbanen's grandstand in 1925]] The initiative to build a grass field at Holmen came from M. W. Aas, who had visited [[Vienna]] in 1915 and had observed the possibilities created there. He gained the support from Mercantile SFK and later also Ready. To construct the venue the limited company A/S Græsbanen was incorporated on 3 April 1916 with a share capital of 42,000 [[Norwegian krone]] (NOK). Ready and Mercantile appointed an equal number of board members in the company.Andersen: 381 [[Stavanger Stadion]] opened with Norway's first grass pitch in 1917. The success of the [[1917 Norwegian Football Cup Final|1917 Cup Final]] demonstrated the qualities of a grass field and resulted in NFF establishing a fund which could lend money to clubs intending to build a grass pitch.Larsen: 85 Gressbanen was the first venue to be lent money through the arrangement, receiving funding for the stands. As the first grass field in the capital, Gressbanen was also selected as the home venue of the national team.Larsen: 86 Construction was supported financially by among others NFF president [[Daniel Eie]] and director [[Johan Throne Holst]]. The lot, at the time in [[Aker, Norway|Aker]], was owned by shipowner [[Olaf Ditlev-Simonsen]] and donated the land to the company. He also paid for a road, water and sewer line to the venue.Andersen: 381–382 The official opening of Gressbanen took place on 1 September 1918, in front of an audience of 10,000. The opening match was between a combined Kristiania team and [[AIK Fotboll|AIK]] from Stockholm.Andersen: 382 The venue was inaugurated as a national stadium the following year. NFF remained a tenant at Gressbanen until 1926, when it moved its games to the newly constructed Ullevaal Stadion, which also served as the home of [[Lyn Fotball|Lyn]].Larsen: 88 Gressbanen was iced for the first time in 1932.Stang: 47 The combination of natural grass and natural ice gave poor conditions for both bandy and football players. Lack of refrigeration caused the ice to only lay during the coldest part of the winter. The ice took its toll on the grass, causing it to not have grown properly until midway through the summer season. Increased population further raised the number of recreational teams which played on the field, causing further wear as 35 teams were scheduled to play on the two fields. Ready therefore took initiative to upgrade the venue as a combined artificial turf and artificial ice stadium, similar to the solution chosen at [[Skien Isstadion]].{{cite news |title=Kunstis og kunstgress på samme flate Ready vil ha helårsbane |last=Hole |first=Arne |work=[[Aftenposten Aften]] |date=6 December 1999 |page=20 |language=Norwegian}} Oslo Municipality granted NOK 7.7 million for the first part of construction in March 2000, which in addition to other funding secured the necessary NOK 13.4 million for the first stage. This consisted of the laying of refrigeration tubes under the soil and the artificial turf. The construction of pumps and cooling central was delayed till the second stage.{{cite news |title=Kunstgress og kunstis på samme sted Ready får helårsbane|last=Hole |first=Arne |work=[[Aftenposten Aften]] |date=9 March 2000 |page=23 |language=Norwegian}} The first stage opened on 18 August 2001.{{cite news |title=Kombinert-anlegg gir bredde og resultater |last=Hole |first=Arne |work=[[Aftenposten Aften]] |date=9 March 2000 |page=23 |language=Norwegian}} The artificial ice facilities were completed in 2004. Thus Gressbanen was the third bandy field in Oslo to receive artificial ice and the eleventh overall in Norway.{{cite web |url=http://www.bandyforbundet.no/bandy/anlegg.asp |title=Anlegg |publisher=Norwegian Bandy Federation |language=Norwegian |accessdate=3 December 2013}} ==Facilities== Gressbanen consists of two playing fields and is located in the Holmen neighborhood of [[Vestre Aker]] in Oslo. The venues are owned by Oslo Municipality and operated by Ready. The larger venue features artificial turf during summer and artificial ice during winter, while the smaller venue has gravel during summer and natural ice during winter.{{cite web |url=http://www.bymiljoetaten.oslo.kommune.no/idrett_og_fritid/alle_idrettsanlegg/article127723-36269.html |title=Gressbanen Ready|publisher=Oslo Municipality |language=Norwegian |accessdate=3 December 2013}} The main surface measures {{convert|105|by|65|m|sp=us}},{{cite web |url=http://www.fotball.no/Community/Anlegg/Hjem/?fiksId=2761 |title=Gressbanen kunstgress |publisher=Football Association of Norway |language=Norwegian |accessdate=3 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130703143539/http://www.fotball.no/Community/Anlegg/Hjem/?fiksId=2761 |archivedate=3 July 2013 |df= }} while the smaller field measures {{convert|89|by|49|m|sp=us}}.{{cite web |url=http://www.fotball.no/Community/Anlegg/Hjem/?fiksId=2764 |title=Gressbanen grus |publisher=Football Association of Norway |language=Norwegian |accessdate=3 December 2013}} Both are illuminated at 100 [[lux]]. The main field is one of nineteen artificial bandy rinks in Norway.{{cite web |url=http://www.bandyforbundet.no/bandy/anlegg.asp |title=Anlegg |publisher=Norwegian Bandy Federation |language=Norwegian |accessdate=3 December 2013}} Football is played from early March through the end of October, while the field is iced for bandy from 1 November to early March. ==Events== [[File:Gressbanen football 1925.jpg|thumb|An international football match in 1925]] [[File:Gressbanen IMG 6149.JPG|thumb|Ready playing a [[Norwegian Bandy Premier League]] match against [[Ullevål IL]] in 2011]] Two cup finals have been held at Gressbanen. The [[1920 Norwegian Football Cup Final|1920 edition]] saw [[Ørn-Horten]] beat [[Frigg FK|Frigg]] 1–0 in front of 14,000 spectators.{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.no/1920/fcup |title=Cup final in Kristiania, October 17 |publisher=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation]] |accessdate=4 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080524093119/http://www.rsssf.no/1920/fcup |archivedate=24 May 2008 |df= }} The [[1921 Norwegian Football Cup Final|following year]] Frigg took revenge by beating [[Odds BK|Odd]] 2–0 in front of 20,000 spectators.{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.no/1921/fcup |title=Cup final in Kristiania, October 17 |publisher=[[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation]] |accessdate=4 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080524093129/http://www.rsssf.no/1921/fcup |archivedate=24 May 2008 |df= }} The venue was the home of the Norway national football team from 1919 to 1926, with an additional match played in 1927. The stadium's record attendance of 20,000 took place at the 14 September 1924 match against [[Denmark national football team|Denmark]]. {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |+ International matches ! revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=February 2012}} {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = International Polo Club Palm Beach | logo_image = [[File:International_Polo_Club_Palm_Beach_logo.png|International Polo Club Palm Beach logo]] | image = [[File:International Polo Club Palm Beach Stadium.jpg|300px|International Polo Club main stadium]] | location = 3667 120th Avenue South
[[Wellington, Florida]]
[[United States]] | coordinates = {{Coord|26|37|41|N|80|14|23|W|region:US-FL_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | opened = 2002 | surface = Natural Grass | capacity = Main Stadium - 1,640
The Pavilion - 500
Tailgating - 40 spots (480 people) | dimensions = 300 yards long by 160 yards wide | acreage = 300 | website = {{URL|http://www.internationalpoloclub.com}} }} The '''International Polo Club Palm Beach''', located in [[Wellington, Florida|Wellington]], [[Florida]], is one of the largest [[polo]] clubs in the world. The club includes several natural grass polo fields, two of which are part of stadiums. ==History== Once home to humble agricultural lands, Wellington, Florida, has been developed into a world-famous [[Horse community|equestrian community]]. The sport of polo has been a major contributor to the city's development. In 1978, [[William T. Ylvisaker]] created polo fields and introduced the mallet and ball game to the city. In the late 1990s, private polo fields owned by [[Summerfield Johnston, Jr.]], Mickey Tarnapol, and [[John B. Goodman (industrialist/polo magnate)|John B. Goodman]] were combined to create a platform for [[Polo handicap|high-goal]] competition. In 2002, John B. Goodman, [[Patronage#Sports|patron]] of the Isla Carroll Polo team, took stewardship of these fields and founded the International Polo Club Palm Beach (IPC). The club then gained the guardianship of the 26-goal C.V. Whitney Cup polo tournament. In 2004, IPC set forth on its inaugural season while construction of the clubhouse and stadium were underway. In the following years, more polo fields were added, along with grandstands, private boxes, and other amenities. In 2013, IPC celebrated its 10th anniversary season. ==Amenities== The main stadium holds approximately 1,640 spectators, making it the largest structure for viewing polo in the United States. Championship Field is used for Sunday matches during the winter season, and also for USPA junior polo tournaments, summer sports, equestrian-themed weddings, and corporate events. The club has nine polo fields, an Olympic-size pool, a spa and fitness center, and a tournament-approved croquet lawn and club. It also has two tennis courts and a tennis pavilion, a wine room, and the largest collection of polo books on earth. The restaurant seats 120 and is named The Mallet Grille after its famous mallet sculpture centerpiece designed by M. Maison, the club’s designer. The centerpiece contains 120 mallets metaphorically representing the capacity of the restaurant. Lance is the Maitre' D/ assistant manager of the restaurant and a great asset to the club. The club bar is called the 7th Chukker. The Pavilion is located across from Championship Field and is used for special functions, including Sunday Brunch and Polo, which is a mainstay during the 16-week winter season. The Pavilion seats 500 and has a large commercial kitchen, its own culinary staff separate from the club, and a covered veranda with views of the polo field. ==22 goal polo tournaments== *C.V. Whitney Cup *USPA Gold Cup® *U.S. Open Polo Championship® ==Other sporting events== IPC hosts non-polo sporting events, including the Junior District Lacrosse Championship, [[American Youth Soccer Organization]] National Games, Ultimate Frisbee Tournaments, the National Field Hockey Championship, and the National Field Hockey Festival, among others. ==Past tenants== From 2000-2008, IPC was the home venue for the [[Palm Beach Pumas]], a member of the [[USL Premier Development League]]. IPC was a major sponsor of the Pumas. ==Management== John A. Wash, CCM{{Cite web|title = John A. Wash CCM Official Website|url = http://johnwashccm.com|accessdate = 2015-09-14}} was President of Club Operations since 2007. He was fired when new owners took over the club in 2017. *Expansion of the polo facility, which includes a private club for members that features The Mallet Grille and The 7th Chukker *Expansion of stadium seating, with private boxes for members and select guests *Addition of several new, professional polo fields for weekday competition *Expansion of the Pavilion from a tent to a 12,000-square-foot dining facility ==External links== * [http://www.internationalpoloclub.com Official website] ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Sports venues in Florida]] [[Category:Polo clubs in the United States]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Florida]] [[Category:Tennis venues in Florida]] [[Category:Wellington, Florida]] [[Category:2002 establishments in Florida]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2002]]

{{see also|2006 in sports|Portal:Sports}} {{Events by month|2006|in sports}}__NOTOC__ {{Month year in topic|July 2006|sports|anchor=dmy}} {| class="infobox" style="width:18em" | ==Deaths== {{main article|Deaths in July 2006}} * [[1 July|1]] [[Fred Trueman]]http://sport.independent.co.uk/cricket/article1153626.ece * [[30 July|30]] [[Al Balding]]http://www.cbc.ca/sports/story/2006/07/31/al-balding-golf.html?ref=rss ==Sporting seasons== *[[Auto racing]] [[:Category:2006 in motorsport|2006]]: **[[2006 Formula One season|Formula One]];  [[2006 GP2 Series season|GP2]];  [[2006 British Touring Car Championship season|BTCC]] **[[2006 in IRL|Indy Racing League]] **[[2006 in NASCAR|NASCAR]];  [[2006 in NASCAR Busch Series|Busch]];  [[2006 in NASCAR Craftsman Truck Series|Craftsman Truck]] **[[World Rally Championship 2006 results|World Rally Championship]] *[[Basketball]]: 2006 college basketball season in the Philippines: **[[NCAA Season 82]] **[[UAAP Season 69]] *[[Cricket]] [[International cricket in 2006|2006]]: [[2006 English cricket season|England]] *[[Football (soccer)|Football]] [[:Category:2006 in association football|2006–07]]: **[[2006–07 UEFA Champions League]] **[[2006–07 UEFA Cup]] *[[Rugby union]] 2006: **[[2006 Air New Zealand Cup]] **[[2006 Currie Cup]] **[[2006 North America 4]] *[[Sports in the United States|U.S.]] and [[Sports in Canada|Canadian sports]] 2005–06: **[[2006 in baseball|2006 MLB season]] **[[2006 CFL season]] |} ==Days of the month==
===31 July 2006 (Monday)=== *[[Baseball]]: The [[Chicago Cubs]] trade four-time [[Cy Young Award]] winner [[Greg Maddux]] to the [[Los Angeles Dodgers]] for middle-infielder [[César Izturis]]. ([https://sports.yahoo.com/mlb/news;_ylt=Atr9cqTBFFUerNTksNwcOSQ5nYcB?slug=ap-cubs-dodgerstrade&prov=ap&type=lgns AP via Yahoo]) *[[Cricket]]: [[South African cricket team in Sri Lanka in 2006|South Africa in Sri Lanka]] **'''[[Test cricket|First Test]] at [[Colombo]] ([[Sinhalese Sports Club Ground|SSCG]]):''' [[Sri Lanka national cricket team|Sri Lanka]] defeats [[South Africa national cricket team|South Africa]] by an innings and 153 runs. South Africa, led by [[Ashwell Prince]], batted first after winning the toss, compiling 169 before being dismissed on the first-day tea break. Sri Lanka lost two early wickets before a record-breaking 624 run partnership between [[Kumar Sangakkara]] (287) and captain [[Mahela Jayawardene]] (374; 26 runs short of [[Brian Lara]]'s world-record individual score of 400). This partnership was particularly savage on [[Spin bowling|spinner]] [[Nicky Boje]], who ended with bowling figures of 0/221 from 65 overs. Sri Lanka were able to [[Declaration and forfeiture#Declaration|declare]] their innings closed at 756/5, leaving South Africa needing 587 runs just to make the home side bat again. Despite an opening partnership of 165, and solid performances in the middle order, [[Muttiah Muralitharan]]'s 6/131 restricted South Africa to 434. Sri Lanka leads to two-Test series 1–0. [http://content-aus.cricinfo.com/slvrsa/engine/match/249193.html (Scorecard)]
===30 July 2006 (Sunday)=== *[[Baseball]]: The [[New York Yankees]] acquire [[Major League Baseball All-Star Game|All-Star]] [[right fielder]] [[Bobby Abreu]] and [[starting pitcher]] [[Cory Lidle]] from the [[Philadelphia Phillies]] for [[relief pitcher]] [[Matt Smith (baseball)|Matt Smith]] and three minor-league prospects. *[[American football]]: [[Heisman Trophy]] winner [[Reggie Bush]] agrees to a six-year contract with the [[New Orleans Saints]]. ([https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/news;_ylt=AgDZqlllIH8NqVzkAd1sZNM5nYcB?slug=ap-saints-bush&prov=ap&type=lgns AP via Yahoo])
===29 July 2006 (Saturday)=== *[[Baseball]]: [[Tampa Bay Devil Rays]] [[third baseman]] [[Tomás Pérez]] ties a major-league record by hitting four doubles in the Devil Rays' 19–6 blowout of the [[New York Yankees]]. Perez, who goes 5-for-5, is the first Devil Rays player to hit four doubles in a game. [https://sports.yahoo.com/mlb/recap;_ylt=Aov4X9FIuY9BaKlOw9f.TL45nYcB?gid=260729110&prov=ap (AP via Yahoo)] *[[Cricket]]: [[Pakistani cricket team in England in 2006|Pakistan in England]]: **'''[[Test cricket|Second Test]] at [[Old Trafford Cricket Ground|Old Trafford]], [[Manchester]]:''' [[England cricket team|England]] defeats [[Pakistan national cricket team|Pakistan]] by an innings and 120 runs. Pakistan's decision to bat first after winning the toss proved disastrous, as the visitors were dismissed for a meagre 119 in their first innings, English [[fast bowling|fast bowler]] [[Steve Harmison]] claiming 6/19. England's reply of 461/9 [[Declaration and forfeiture#Declaration|declared]] centred on centuries to [[Alastair Cook]] (127) and [[Ian Bell]] (106 not out). Player-of-the-match Harmison (5/57) and [[Monty Panesar]] (5/72) combined to dismiss Pakistan for 222 in its second innings. England leads the four-Test series 1–0. [http://content-aus.cricinfo.com/engvpak/engine/match/225256.html (Scorecard)] *[[Rugby union]]: **[[2006 Tri Nations Series]]; round 4 at [[Suncorp Stadium]], [[Brisbane]], Australia. ***{{ru|AUS}} 9–13 {{ru|NZL}} ****The All Blacks brush aside [[2006 Kapa O Pango controversy|criticism earlier in the week]] about their [[Haka of the All Blacks#Kapa O Pango (the new All Blacks' haka)|Kapa O Pango haka]], retaining the [[Bledisloe Cup]] for the third year in succession and picking up 4 Tri Nations points. All Black winger [[Joe Rokocoko]] scored the match's only try, and a second half [[Drop goal#Rugby union|drop goal]] to [[Daniel Carter (rugby player)|Daniel Carter]] gave the All Blacks enough breathing space in a tight match. [[Stirling Mortlock]] kicked 3 penalties for Australia. **[[2006 North America 4]]: Championship Final ***Canada West defeats United States Falcons 30–21 to win inaugural tournament in [[Columbus, Ohio]]. ****An intercept try to West's centre [[Akio Tyler]] on 60' seals the match.[http://www.narugby.com/news/072920062.html (NA4)] **[[2006 Air New Zealand Cup]]: Round 1 ***Pool A: [[Manawatu Rugby Union|Manawatu]] 10–41 [[Auckland Rugby Football Union|Auckland]]
===28 July 2006 (Friday)=== *[[Baseball]]: The [[Milwaukee Brewers]] trade [[Major League Baseball All-Star Game|All-Star]] [[outfielder]] [[Carlos Lee]] to the [[Texas Rangers (baseball)|Texas Rangers]] for [[relief pitcher]] [[Francisco Cordero]] and outfielders [[Kevin Mench]] and [[Laynce Nix]]. *[[American football]]: [[Willie Roaf]], the [[Kansas City Chiefs]]' 11-time [[Pro Bowl]] [[offensive tackle]], announces his retirement. ([https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/news;_ylt=Ap0v6al7h8eGEgu4QJCUIGk5nYcB?slug=ap-chiefs-roaf&prov=ap&type=lgns AP via Yahoo]) *[[Basketball]]: The first round of eliminations in the [[NCAA Season 82|men's basketball tournament]] of the [[Philippine NCAA]] ends with the [[San Beda Red Lions]] beating the defending champion [[Letran Knights]], 57–49. Both the Red Lions and the Knights finished with a 6 win-1 loss record, while the [[PCU Dolphins]] are third with 5–2, and the [[Mapúa Cardinals]] are fourth with 4–3. Rounding out the competition are the [[San Sebastian Stags]] (3–4), the [[UPHSD Altas]] (2–5) and the season host [[St. Benilde Blazers]] and [[JRU Heavy Bombers]] (both 1–6). [http://www.ubelt.com/ub/ncaa/mbb/story.aspx?id=1132 UBelt.com] *[[Rugby union]]: **[[2006 Kapa O Pango controversy]] ***In reply, [[All Blacks]]' coach, [[Graham Henry]], today said that Australians should look at their own society and background, before criticising other countries.[http://www.newstalkzb.co.nz/newsdetail1.asp?storyID=100521 (NewstalkZB)] **[[2006 Air New Zealand Cup]]: Round One ***Pool B: [[Hawke's Bay Rugby Union|Hawke's Bay]] 0– 45 [[Canterbury Rugby Football Union|Canterbury]] in [[Napier, New Zealand]].
===27 July 2006 (Thursday)=== *[[Rugby union]]: [[2006 Kapa O Pango controversy]] **[[Australian national rugby union team|Australian Wallabies]] coach, [[John Connolly (rugby)|John Connolly]], calls for the [[Haka of the All Blacks#Kapa O Pango (the new All Blacks' haka)|Kapa O Pango]] haka of the New Zealand [[All Blacks]] to be banned, stating that the throat-slitting action at the end is a bad example. "Young sportsmen these days copy the Wallabies, they copy the All Blacks, and I'd hate to think it led to a tragic consequence somewhere down the road" Connolly said.[http://www.theage.com.au/news/Sport/All-Blacks-coach-slams-haka-criticism/2006/07/28/1153816359796.html (TheAge)] *[[Cycling]]: [[2006 Tour de France]] winner [[Floyd Landis]] tests positive for a banned substance, [[testosterone (medication)|testosterone]], given after Stage 16 of the race. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/other_sports/cycling/5221122.stm (BBC)], [http://www.velonews.com/news/fea/10590.0.html (VeloNews)] *[[American football]]: [[Pro Bowl]] [[center (American football)|center]] [[LeCharles Bentley]], whom the [[Cleveland Browns]] had signed to anchor their [[offensive line]], tears a [[tendon]] in his knee and is out for the entire 2006 season. ([[Center (American football)|AP via Yahoo]]) *[[Football (soccer)]]: [[2006–07 UEFA Cup]]: First Qualifying Round, second leg.
